Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: The team awaits a clarification before progressing with a shared task.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: My phone buzzed with a new email just as I was about to leave for my volunteer shift. The subject line read, “Urgent: Need Clarification Before Proceeding.” I glanced at the clock—if I didn’t leave now, I’d be late unlocking the community center, where a small crowd would already be waiting for breakfast service. As the only volunteer scheduled this morning, everyone depended on me to open the doors and get things started. But my team at work was also waiting; they couldn’t move forward on our project until I responded. I could picture my colleagues refreshing their inboxes, growing frustrated with the delay. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations: be a reliable teammate, or be the dependable volunteer the community counted on. I stood frozen in my hallway, phone in hand, torn between two places I needed to be at once.
